 CAMBRIDGE — Seeing herself as a voice for Federalsburg's Haitian community, Gelard Merilus Loulou attended the Cambridge Woman's Club Friday to gather helpful information that she can take back to Federalsburg.Friday afternoon, the club hosted Lindsay Waite, a retired attorney who currently volunteers at the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center in Easton to help those who are applying for United States citizenship prepare.
Merilus Loulou said Federalsburg's Haitian community is "in crisis," with many fearful about what could happen in the county in the coming months when it comes to immigration.
With a new administration in the White House, there has been a push to crack down on illegal immigration, which has caused concern among migrants in the United States.
During her presentation, Waite spoke about the process for naturalization in the U.S. She explained that to gain citizenship, a person must file a Form N-400 application for naturalization, have their biometrics taken, pass a background check, pass the citizenship test and complete an interview with U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services. If the person is approved after these steps, they will need to take the Oath of Allegiance at a naturalization ceremony.
Waite said she believes the process costs about $800 to complete.
At the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, Waite and other volunteers help prepare those with green cards who want to obtain citizenship. She said volunteers help go over the Form N-400 application, review questions that could be on the test and practice reading and writing.
Waite said the citizenship test includes an English portion and also asks questions about democracy, the constitution, history and geography.
Offering some of the more difficult questions to the audience at the event, Waite said the people she works with come in for about 10 weeks to review questions and practice English.
"They learn a lot more than I think my nephew, who went to high school and college, could probably know," she said, causing people in the audience to laugh.
Claudia White-Cooke and Joyce Dowling, who attended Waite's presentation, said after hearing some of the questions on the test, they weren't sure if they'd be able to pass it. White-Cooke said the process to become a citizen seems complicated and the people who apply are really committed.
When one person at the event asked if the new presidential administration has affected the naturalization process at all, Waite — who said she is not an expert on what's happening at the national level — said she did notice a change in priority for legal entry into the U.S. from Venezuela.
"To a limit, a certain number of people from Venezuela were being given entry legally and now that's stopped," she said.
Waite said she believes the naturalization process in the U.S. will continue, however. She said people still want to be American citizens.
"And I and others will do what we can to help," she said.
Those who are interested in volunteering with the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center or want to learn more can call 877-772-9832 or visit chesmrc.org.

title: Fountain case sparked animosity between papers
author: JOSEPH KOPER
content:
Fountain case sparked animosity between papers

 February 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOSEPH KOPER | Section: Columns 
 
 1200
 Words 

 Read News Document

 During the two-plus years of the contentious Isaiah Fountain case (1919-1921), Easton and Talbot County were rocked with many controversies and side stories that derived from the the original case. In April 1919, Isaiah Fountain — an African American — was accused of raping a local white girl. Fountain's case generated hundreds of news articles relating to his case resulting from: his two trials and convictions, multiple lynching attempts, two escapes and manhunts, armed infantry troops surrounding the Talbot County courthouse, questionable court decisions and his controversial execution.The general sentiment in conservative Talbot County was that Fountain was guilty of raping the white girl. Of course, during the Jim Crow era, any allegations of sexual or even suspicious social contact between a Black man and a white female were taken extremely seriously by the white population. During this period there were many locals who felt the need to to resort to the "Lynch Law." Similar sentiments were echoed — or even promoted — by the Easton Star-Democrat. Contrary viewpoints were quickly and passionately disputed by the paper. As with most local editors of the era, though, the Star-Democrat's Samuel E. Shannahan was determined to present Easton and Talbot County in the best light possible.
According to Norman Harrington's book, "Easton Album," Shannahan was the longtime editor of the Easton Star-Democrat. Harrington described Shannahan as: "chauvinistic, elevating the interests of Talbot County above all else." Shannahan was the ultimate local "booster" for Talbot County and didn't stand for any criticism about his home county.
Certainly, he didn't accept the implications of Lynch Law, Jim Crow, mob violence and racism that the events of Fountain case cast over Easton and Talbot County. He was determined to uphold the honor and reputation of his hometown, regardless of what "outside" publications printed.
The Baltimore newspapers (Sun, Evening Sun, News and Afro-American) viewed the Fountain case with a somewhat more balanced journalistic eye. They generally reported evidence that suggested that Isaiah Fountain was innocent of the rape charges.
The reporting of the "big city" newspapers infuriated editor Harrington, who took issue with just about everything the the Baltimore papers printed. When the Baltimore papers reported that a 2,000-person mob attempted to lynch Isaiah Fountain, the Easton weekly minimized the lynching attempt and blamed the "excitement," on people from other counties or troublemakers from Delaware.
Shannahan was furious that the Baltimore press would dare impugn the dignity of local citizens by reporting opposing accounts of events. A Star-Democrat editorial labeled the "big city" newsmen as "a mob of cub reporters" and called their reporting "not only unfair but disgusting." In another article the Star-Democrat used bold type to complain: "Of all the things to be resented, next to the crime itself, the absolute contempt for the truth, the utter barefaced lies published by the press of Baltimore city, is most to be condemned."
In short, there was very little that the Baltimore and Easton papers agreed upon regarding the Fountain case. This visceral journalistic animosity even extended beyond the matters of the Fountain case. For example — in an attempt to mend journalistic fences — the Baltimore News sent a reporter to Easton to write a sort of travelogue about the town. The News published the article on Sunday, Feb. 1, 1920, and the Star-Democrat reprinted the story a week later.
Surprisingly, the local press expressed dissatisfaction with the article and ignored its very positive depictions of Easton. A person reading the story today, would think that it was crafted by a public relations firm hired by the Easton Chamber of Commerce. Still the article's praise for Easton didn't matter to the local weekly. The paper continued its journalistic feud with the Baltimore News by it's headline for the story it reprinted on Feb. 7, 1920: "Says Easton is slow/Baltimore news man does not flatter Talbot's county seat in review in Sunday's issue/Says we pride ourselves on quality instead of quantity — sees us as serene and satisfied'
The Star-Democrat prefaced the News article with this statement: "Some of the story is good, some untrue, and none of it as good as Easton is entitled to." Today, a reader of the article would probably agree that Easton was as desirable a place to visit and live then as it is now.
The only comments that I could discern as being even remotely negative involved the "high cost of living" (i.e., the "two-bit" bus ride from the railroad station) and this statement: "... Easton, Talbot's lovely county seat, grows with that slowness that is akin to sureness. ..."
The article is chock full of complements, calling Easton: "Serene and satisfied" and "lovely." The article praises "the well-paved thoroughfares," "charming homes" and "ancient and worthy trees." The Baltimore News reporter wrote with awe about visiting The Old Friends Meeting House and described his visit to the nearby Wye House and its "wonderful old garden." He called the Wye House "one of the most beautiful and historical estates on the Eastern Shore."
Reading the Baltimore News review about Easton over a century later, I confess that I don't understand the Star-Democrat's stubborn viewpoint about the article being "untrue" or unkind to Easton. The apparently offending comment about Easton's "slowness that is akin to sureness", strikes me as a very positive comment.
The complaint about the "high cost of living" and the "two bits" it cost for transportation from the train station are hardly condemnations, but merely observations that many of us might make today about the economy. The Baltimore News reporter gushed with praise for Easton, describing it as: "this attractive town" "Easton gives constant pleasure to the artistic eye" and "well-groomed, well-bred, and unobtrusive."
The writer also portrayed the town as "lovely", and "the most pleasing of the larger cities of the Eastern Shore." The News reporter then described Easton as: "the Queen City of the glorious Eastern Shore of Maryland" and "richly endowed by nature as a manufacturing center and place of residence." The reporter praised the "well-paved" streets, "splendid sidewalks" and the sewerage system "of the most advanced type." The article even cited the town's "efficient lighting plant," and its plan to purchase a modern motor fire engine."
After reading the Star-Democrat's hyper-critical and fussy comments about the Baltimore News article, one must ask: "What's wrong about this gushing review of Easton?" The News article about Easton sure makes it seem like the kind of place one would like to visit or live. I think most readers would agree that the lovely town of Easton is still much the same as described in the newspaper article from over a century ago — except for the century-old vitriol shown for the "big city papers" and the comment about having to spend "two bits to ride in the omnibus."
With his stanch anti-Fountain editorial viewpoint and disdain for "big city" newspapers, Editor Samuel Shannahan remained fiercely devoted to his hometown and the Easton Star-Democrat. Under his editorship, in 1937 the Maryland Press Association named the Easton Star-Democrat as the best weekly newspaper in Maryland. Ever the newsman, Shannahan died on December 7, 1942, while working at his editor's desk — some 22 years after he declared the Isaiah Fountain case to be "... one of the most noted in the State's annals."

Harriet Tubman, an abolitionist and social activist who was born into and escaped from slavery in Dorchester County in the 19th century, became well known for her work on the Underground Railroad, a network of routes and safe houses that helped slaves escape to their freedom. At the Harriet Tubman Museum and Educational Center in Cambridge, visitors can learn about the legacies of Tubman and other influential African Americans from the Eastern Shore.

title: An age in America comes to an end
author: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library
content:
An age in America comes to an end

 May 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Columns 
 
 890
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The small town of Oroville, California, drifted into the 20th century as a shadow of its former self.Back in 1848, when gold was discovered in the area, prospectors had poured into the place. But by 1900 the vein had long since petered out, and the town had become little more than an agricultural backwater.
Meanwhile, the modern world marched on. In Los Angeles, California's first movie theater opened for business in 1902. The next year, the Wright brothers made the first heavier-than air flight at Kitty Hawk. And in 1908, Henry Ford brought the automobile within reach of everyday Americans when he introduced the reliable, relatively inexpensive Model T.
Still, news of these wonders would have arrived in Oroville as little more than rumors of a wider, more sophisticated world.
Then, on Aug. 29, 1911, a teenaged layabout named Floyd Hefner strode into the corral of the local slaughterhouse, intending to hitch up a team of horses, and found a nearly naked man leaning unsteadily against a fence-post. The last living member of a Native American tribe had come in from the cold.
Perhaps not surprisingly for the time and place, guns were drawn, dogs were held at bay, and someone used the telephone in the slaughterhouse to call the law. By the time the sheriff arrived, a butcher's cloak had been thrown over the shoulders of the man, who spoke no language anyone understood. The sheriff handcuffed the man, drove him into town in a wagon (the first time in his life he'd ever ridden in a wheeled vehicle), and locked him up in the county jail.
It wasn't long before newspapers throughout the state were reporting the discovery of America's "last wild Indian." Learning of the news, Alfred Kroeber, a renowned professor of anthropology at the University of California, Berkeley, sent a colleague, Thomas Waterman, up to Oroville.
Meeting with the prisoner in his cell, Waterman thought he might be speaking a language related to the Yana tongue. Waterman knew a little Yana, and when he tried it out on the prisoner, the man's face lit up.
For the first time since the only other members of his Yahi band had died, he had heard another human being speak a word or two he understood.
Waterman was able to ask the man his name. Using a combination of gestures and simple Yahi, the man explained that in his culture it was taboo to speak his name aloud to someone else until another member of his tribe had formally introduced him. As this was now impossible, Waterman ended up simply calling him "Man" in the Yahi tongue.
And so it is that this Native American man comes down to us in history under the false name of "Ishi." We will never know what his real name was.
Waterman's fellow professor at Berkeley, Alfred Kroeber, was a remarkable man. He had earned his doctorate in 1901 from Columbia University, studying under Franz Boaz, the father of modern anthropology. Kroeber took Ishi in and gave him a place to live in the university's museum, where Ishi worked as a janitor. This allowed Kroeber and the other anthropologists in his department to study Ishi closely over the remaining five years of his life.
You might expect that much of what Kroeber and Waterman learned from Ishi would have been horrifying. This was a man who, from boyhood, watched his tribe and immediate family whittled down by ceaseless slaughter. Norman Kingsley, an eager participant in one of the last massacres, later recounted that, in the middle of his attack, he exchanged his .56 caliber Spencer rifle for a .38 caliber pistol, because the rifle "tore them up so bad," especially the babies.
But after his introduction into modernizing California, accounts say Ishi didn't speak of the horrors he'd witnessed, nor did he give in to melancholy or despair. He adapted with grace to his new life and embraced many of the changes happening in the world around him.
I learned of Ishi from Alfred Kroeber's wife and fellow anthropologist Theodora Kracaw Kroeber, who, in 1961, wrote "Ishi in Two Worlds," now considered a classic of modern anthropology. I first read the book 40 years ago, and rereading it recently, I found myself placing Theodora Kroeber in the same league as Claude Lévi-Strauss. Without ever leaving any of her anthropological principles behind, she consistently writes clear, compelling prose.
It isn't easy reading the first part of Kroeber's book, watching as Ishi and the remaining members of his band are forced to withdraw further and further from the whites encroaching upon their world; until, finally, they retreat into that world's last untouched cañon, and, ultimately, its last bushy slopes.
But Kroeber's description of the way Ishi handles the world he is then brought into, the way he maintains his Yahi dignity in the face of that world's awesome power (while never losing his ability to see through its sometimes absurd idiosyncrasies) is somehow reassuring. It gave me hope for humanity at large.
I reread "Ishi in Two Worlds" thanks to an Inter-Library Loan, but a copy of the book has now been placed in our collection at the Talbot County Free Library. You'll find it in the Easton library on the Biography shelves under the call letters ISHI. If you're in St. Michaels, you can place a reserve on the book and it will be sent down there for you.

title: Plaque honors hundreds of Black Civil War soldiers from Queen Anne's County
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com

Plaque honors hundreds of Black Civil War soldiers from Queen Anne's County

 May 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News

 A new memorial plaque at the Kennard African American Cultural Heritage Center in Centreville recognizes approximately 435 Black soldiers from Queen Anne's County who fought for the Union Army during the Civil War, filling a gap in local history and honoring their profound impact on the community. Local veterans and residents gathered April 28 to dedicate the monument to these long-overlooked heroes.The soldiers served in the United States Colored Troops, which consisted of free and enslaved African Americans who fought for the Union during the Civil War. Queen Anne's County has identified about 435 men from across the county who served in these units, according to local historian Chris Pupke.
Maryland contributed more than 8,000 men to the United States Colored Troops, and by the end of the war, Black soldiers represented about 10% of the Union force, he said.
Queen Anne's County soldiers predominantly served in the 19th, 39th and 7th regiments, and participated in battles and sieges instrumental to turning the tide of the war and shaping the history of the divided nation, he said.
"These men, these heroes, fought, bled and died for this country and we are grateful," Pupke said.
Following the war, these men started schools, built churches, searched for loved ones sold into slavery, and helped create the community known today, he said.
"Too often today their stories remain missing from our history books, from our community conversations, and from family histories," Pupke said.
While more work is necessary to continually recognize the tremendous sacrifices made for freedom, "today we celebrate these heroes, their bravery and sacrifices, accomplishments and contributions to our community," he said.
An initiative more than a year in the making, members of the Centreville Veterans Information Committee as well as local artists, masons, community members and county commissioners helped bring the project to fruition.
Kennard African American Cultural Heritage Center Executive Director Tara Coursey noted it was incredible to recognize the legacies of county Civil War soldiers.
Kennard stands as the repository of African American history in the county, so it is only fitting the plaque found a home there, she said.
Performing a dedication prayer, Deacon Frank Hessen of St. Christopher's said, "With courage born of hope they marched from this very soil answering the call to defend the dignity of all people and forge a nation united in liberty. Their sacrifice, steadfastness, and unwavering resolve inspire us still, reminding us of the cost of freedom and the power of unity in the face of adversity."
Committee member Robert Simms teared up at the performance of taps dedicating the plaque. As a Vietnam-era veteran, Simms understood the loss of friends to war as well as a lack of recognition upon returning home.
Noting the plaque's meaningfulness to him and others, "It's been a pleasure to be part of this group," Simms said.
The Centreville Veterans Information Committee looks forward to the eventual installation of a 6-foot statue to further honor Queen Anne's County United States Colored Troops.
The committee's Veterans Coffee House welcomes veterans supporting veterans community and conversations every Monday at the American Legion Jeff Davis Post 18 at 11 a.m.

title: Tubman's service did not end with the Underground Railroad
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Tubman's service did not end with the Underground Railroad

 May 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 564
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DORCHESTER COUNTY — Harriet Tubman escaped slavery and became a conductor of the Underground Railroad, leading around 13 missions to free over 70 enslaved individuals around Maryland before the Civil War, but her work didn't stop there.During the war, Tubman was a nurse, Union spy, scout and cook, which prompted the Maryland National Guard to posthumously commission her as a one star general at the American Legion Dorchester Post 91 in Cambridge last year.
Tubman began her service in 1862, when she aided sick and injured Black Union soldiers and newly freed slaves in South Carolina. "And she did it with a massive bounty on her head," said National Underground Railroad Network to Freedom member Bob Nelson.
She managed to evade capture all while operating as an agent for the Union Army.
"Getting into the byways, where she traveled with the enslaved people that she held free, you really get a sense of how rough it was, how remote it was, how terrifying it was at night. And thus the incredible bravery of these people," said Nelson. "And again, in Harriet's case, the bravery to go back into that over and over again. And then go to South Carolina and help with the war."
Two years into the war, under the command of Union Colonel James Montgomery, Tubman became the first female to lead an armed military operation, one that many have called her most extraordinary accomplishment. During the Combahee River Raid, Tubman, Montgomery and 150 Black Union soldiers rescued more than 750 slaves.
The success of the raid is owed to Tubman's intelligence gathering. Tubman learned from those she helped free where the Confederacy hid torpedoes along the river and the proper routes to rescue people.
Alongside freeing over 750 enslaved individuals, Union troops came on shore as slaves boarded the military vessels to destroy influential estates along the river. By the time Confederate forces learned what was happening, most of the damage was done.
Honoring Tubman
To honor Tubman and those she fought alongside this Memorial Day, founder of the Menare Foundation Tony Cohen suggests learning more about her story.
"There is a new book called 'Combee,' which is one of the Pulitzer Prize Winners, and it's about her service to the Union Army in South Carolina," Cohen said.
Cohen is intimately familiar with Tubman's story, having followed in her footsteps in 1996.
"I walked from Montgomery County, Maryland to Canada along the route of the Underground Railroad. And so I walked 10 to 25 miles a day for about seven weeks. I stopped in all the towns along the way asking people what they knew about the Underground Railroad, sought out documentation and historical societies, and museums. I spoke with descendants of those folks who made the journey and those who helped them along the way. And I even stayed in people's houses every night, some of them being stops on the Underground Railroad," Cohen said.
Cohen is planning on commemorating the 30-year anniversary of his journey by doing it again. He wants to bring the story of the Underground Railroad to a new generation while bring attention to our National Parks on the nations 125th anniversary.
"She experienced some of the most harrowing aspects of the slavery system, but her legacy is about pushing through and transcending those situations to bring about change. And I think that's the legacy that folks on the Eastern Shore can be very proud of," said Cohen.

title: Turning back the clock? Five years after George Floyd’s death, race in America faces Trump-driven changes and crossroads
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Turning back the clock? Five years after George Floyd’s death, race in America faces Trump-driven changes and crossroads

 May 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: National 
 
 1397
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the aftermath of the killing of George Floyd in May 2020, Irving Joyner and Rob Carpenter saw some signs of change when it came to race relations in America.Police agencies were pressed for more transparency and greater ability to charge officers accused of wrongdoing. Major employers, federal agencies, universities and progressive communities launched diversity and inclusion initiatives.
Five years after Floyd's death and ensuing protests and unrest, Joyner, a law professor at North Carolina Central University, is less optimistic.
"Now the opposite is occurring," Joyner said. "There is a retrenchment."
He points to efforts by the Trump administration and other conservatives to dismantle diversity, equity and inclusion programs and affirmative action hiring requirements, the directions of policies related to immigration and refugees and rollbacks of legal oversight sought by the Biden administration with the Minneapolis and Louisville police departments after the killings of Floyd and Breonna Taylor in 2020.
"The playbook seems to be pretty clear. There is an effort to undermine all the racial progress," Joyner said, contending DEI programs criticized by conservatives aim to be pathways to seeing the benefits of a pluralistic society.
"We see the parallels and the perils," Joyner said of the current landscape and America's history with race.
'PROTECTING COMMUNiTIES' Since returning to power in January, President Donald Trump has shut down DEI programs (including in the U.S. military) and affirmative action hiring requirements for federal agencies and contractors.
Trump argues for a "merit-based society" and conservatives say DEI and affirmative action policies disadvantage white people and continue to classify people along racial lines.
The U.S. Justice Department on May 21 said that it is dismissing federal lawsuits and proposed consent decrees with police in Minneapolis and Louisville in response to the Floyd and Taylor incidents.
"Overbroad police consent decrees divest local control of policing from communities where it belongs, turning that power over to unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats, often with an anti-police agenda," said Assistant U.S. Attorney General Harmeet Dhillon of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division.
Dhillon said the moves aim to end the Biden administration's "failed experiment of handcuffing local leaders and police departments."
A White House spokesperson said Trump is focused on safety and prosperity "for all Americans" and empowering law enforcement.
"President Trump is tirelessly enacting policies to ensure America's safety, prosperity, and success for all Americans. Through his Make America Safe Again agenda, the Trump Administration is committed to stopping crime, upholding justice, protecting communities, and empowering federal, state, and local law enforcement," said White House spokesperson Harrison Fields.
The White House said the president is not considering a pardon of Derek Chauvin, the Minneapolis police officer convicted of killing Floyd in May 2020.
Trump has pressed the District of Columbia to remove Black Lives Matter street murals near the White House and wants to restore names of military bases that bore the names of Confederate generals.
Joyner and Carpenter, an author and communications professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, feel undercurrents to Trump's rhetoric and agendas.
They see cultural and racial undertones to Trump's hard lines on immigration (including his efforts to end birthright citizenship), his nostalgia for a "Golden Age" of America and his administration's cuts to foreign aid and refugee programs for developing countries while launching a new one for white Afrikaner farmers from South Africa.
"Trump is perceived as turning back the clock," Carpenter said.
'HUMAN NATURE'S SCRIPT'Carpenter sees societal swings after Floyd's death went viral on social media, highlighting police misconduct and America's complicated history of racial and social inequities.
"I do think there has been some progress," Carpenter said, noting some of the efforts related to policing.
But Carpenter said plenty of challenges remain citing research showing 75% of white people do not have friends of color and 66% of Black people don't have any white friends.
Carpenter said African Americans still face obstacles and discrimination with jobs, noting a 2024 study that found job applicants with 'white-sounding' names were 50% more likely to get callbacks from employers than 'Black-sounding' names.
"It's an ongoing trauma. It's still a daily experience," Carpenter said of America's racial challenges.
But he also said the experiences of race in America and the current pushback to diversity and affirmative action programs have global and historical parallels.
"It's all throughout history where a majority population tends to favor themselves and dismiss the complaints of minorities," Carpenter said.
He said when minority rights are focused on, majority populations tend to feel they are being aggrieved.
"It's nothing new under the sun," Carpenter said. "They are just following the human nature script."
ECHO CHAMBERSOthers on the frontlines of the social landscape see a mixed bag with the current state of race in America.
Erica Williams, executive director of A Red Circle, a St. Louis-based racial equity group, welcomed post-Floyd police changes such as body cameras and civilian review boards, but said the community distrust of law enforcement persists.
She said the economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic "deepened every pre-existing divide — especially in food access, education and health care."
Her group has launched community food programs to help with post-pandemic inflation with U.S. prices up 25% since the pandemic.
"We grew more produce, hired youth interns, launched workshops and distributed thousands of pounds of fresh food to families," she said.
Adanté Pointer, a California-based civil rights attorney, sees ups and downs with policing since 2020.
"We are seeing officers prosecuted more frequently than before," he said. "However, police shootings and killings have gone up."
Last year, police killings of civilians totaled 1,365 persons, the highest on record, according to Mapping Police Violence.
There were 1,159 police-involved deaths in 2020.
White people made up 42.7% of the 2024 deaths while accounting for 59% of the total population. Black people accounted for one-quarter of fatal police incidents while making up 13% of the population.
Pointer said the dominance of social media in contemporary discourse offers an opportunity to learn more about others and their paths. But it also mirrors societal biases and beliefs and technology algorithms allow users to stay in their ideological and social lanes.
"It becomes an echo chamber," he said.
GOODBYE DEI?Donald Nieman, a history professor at Binghamton University in New York, sees racial pendulums throughout American history.
He said there has been progress in narrowing racial income, education and employment gaps but worries about Trump "appealing to white grievance."
Neiman said. "It also assumes that Black people have used racism as a weapon to win special privileges at the expense of whites .. It is dangerous: It diverts attention from the real racial disparities in our society and from developing policies to address them."
The U.S. poverty rate stands at 11% with 18% of African-Americans, 17% of Hispanic Americans, 19% of immigrants and 8% of white Americans living in poverty, according to U.S. Census data and FederalSafetyNet.com.
Some of the companies and organizations that embraced DEI efforts after Floyd's death have jettisoned those efforts amid pushback from Trump and conservatives.
Others have faulted DEI programs as patronizing and self-serving.
"DEI is embraced by the business community when they think it will enhance their bottom lines," Pointer said. "They are more than willing to walk away when it's not popular."
Several large U.S. businesses, brands and technology firms have sought warm relations with Trump since he returned to power, attending and bankrolling his inauguration and attending other White House events.
Muneer Panjwani, CEO of Engage for Good (which connects businesses and nonprofits) said DEI programs have driven "meaningful progress."
"Companies have become significantly more aware of systemic racism and structural barriers faced by marginalized communities, taking actionable steps toward equity," he said.
But Panjwani acknowledges Trump has leveraged feelings of alienation among some white people. He also said equity conversations have sometimes been framed too narrowly, overlooking class, gender and other factors.
Carpenter said white working-class Americans, who have seen stagnant wages and high inflation, have felt unheard in contemporary discourses.
All that comes amid post-pandemic financial strains and concentrations of wealth.
"Economic inequality has reached alarming levels, with the richest 1% holding over 31% of the nation's wealth while nearly half of Americans still struggle with unexpected financial burdens," Panjwani said.
Williams said her Missouri-based stays focused on its local work, including a community farm that grows its own food and is looking to offer its own grocery store and food production kitchen.
"We've seen an escalation of rhetoric and policymaking that undermines inclusive education, equity initiatives and even basic access programs. In that environment, I stay focused on building what my community needs," she said
Carpenter agrees that it takes popular and grassroots changes in mindsets to move the needle.
"Politicians never lead," he said.

title: Moore unveils investment into marginalized communities during event on Pine Street
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Moore unveils investment into marginalized communities during event on Pine Street

 June 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Gov. Wes Moore made a historic announcement at the historic Civil Rights meeting ground of Bethel AME Church in Cambridge on Juneteenth.Moore announced the allocation of $400 million to address discriminatory practices like redlining, mass incarceration and urban renewal in over 400 "Just Communities."
Making the announcement at the Pine Street church on the holiday designated to commemorate the ending of slavery in the United States was no coincidence.
"This was the Black Wall Street operating in America," said the Rev. Devan Martin Thursday of Pine Street as he acknowledged the historic significance of the day, place and announcement. Martin energized the people sitting in pews, reminding them of those who have come here before.
"It's not an accident that we've come here on Juneteenth to not only stand on our own two feet, but to stand on the shoulders of our ancestors," he said. "The Harriet Tubmans and Fredrick Douglasses who walked literally enslaved people through these grounds."
Cambridge's past
During a time of civil unrest in Cambridge in the 1960s, Bethel AME served as a headquarters for the Civil Rights Movement, according to Dorchester County's tourism department. Many rallies and meetings were held at the church.
In the early 1960s, unemployment skyrocketed, exposing the Cambridge's severe racial divide. Although segregation was ruled unconstitutional in 1954, Cambridge maintained separate schools and recreational areas in the Second Ward for 10 more years.
Protests endured for weeks in the summer of 1963 after promises of desegregation were backpedaled. Gov. J. Millard Tawes imposed martial law and deployed the Maryland National Guard to Cambridge, where it remained for 25 days. Martial law would remain in effect for a year.
In July of '67, H. Rap Brown, an emerging Black militant and chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, gave a speech in the town. On the corner of Pine and Ceder streets, Brown said, "If this town don't come around, this town should be burned down."
On July 24, 1967, Pine Street went up in flames. The origin of fire remains unclear, though there has been a lot of speculation and finger pointing over the decades. Cambridge's Second Ward is still recovering from the fire, the segregation and the discrimination that followed.
Moore's announcement
A key theme among speakers at the Juneteenth event was that now is the time to rectify systemic and economic injustices affecting the community.
Martin said this will not be a pull-yourselves-up-by-your-bootstraps approach. Instead, a path forward will be provided offering hope beyond self resilience, he said.
At Bethel AME., Moore announced over 400 "Just Communities" in Maryland, including Cambridge. The communities, 419 of Maryland's 1,463 census tracts, were determined by the state's Department of Housing and Community Development to be historically underserved.
According to Moore, $400 million has been designated to address exclusionary policie in these communities. The "Just Community" designations will go into effect July 1.
"Today, Gov. Moore and Sec. (Jake) Day embodied how Maryland is setting a national standard for disrupting systemic inequities and ushering inclusive paths towards healing in and with communities from all zip codes," said Maryland Commission on African American History and Culture Vice Chair Jaelon Moaney, who is from Cambridge, in a press release Thursday.
During his visit to Cambridge, Moore also announced an executive clemency order adding nearly 7,000 cases to his historic June 2024 mass pardon of 175,000 cannabis-related convictions. The 6,938 additional pardons, which are for simple cannabis possession convictions, are "the result of continued partnership with the Maryland Judiciary to review cases since the first order was signed last June," Moore's office said in a press release.
"I also want to be very clear, we are not going to celebrate the benefits of (cannabis) legalization if we do not deal with the consequences of criminalization," Moore said to those gathered at Bethel AME. Thursday.
Moore said both initiatives announced Thursday aim to address the long-term impacts of discrimination like that experienced by Cambridge's Pine Street community.
"Liberation is good, but we demand freedom," Moore said.

title: Cambridge becomes a Just Community
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Cambridge becomes a Just Community

 July 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester

 CAMBRIDGE — On Juneteenth at Bethel AME Church on Pine Street, Gov. Wes Moore announced the Just Communities designation of 419 locations across Maryland, including parts of Cambridge. Moore said it was not a coincidence this announcement was made in a city where the Civil Rights Movement took center stage.The Moore-Miller administration established the Just Communities Designation in 2024 to address policies that have disenfranchised generations of families, such as redlining and exclusionary zoning.
"We wanted to hold it in one of the communities that rose to the top tier of places that had experienced the most harm and from which, the least improvement has occurred," said Secretary of Housing and Community Development Jake Day of the Juneteenth event.
The initiative is the result of work by The Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development Division of Just Communities. Day said he has worked closely with Division of Just Communities Assistant Secretary Cat Goughnour.
Day said the Just Communities Act not only acknowledges past harms but returns resources to those communities. As part of the initiative, Day said Cambridge residents will see community-nominated projects for revitalization, such as facilities, housing and economic developments.
"We want to make sure that we understand what the community wants and not show up with development when people aren't asking for it," he said.
According to Day, early indicators of success for the Just Communities Act would be more project activity in neighborhoods with visible scars, like the Pine Street corridor of Cambridge, formerly known as Black Wall Street.
This could include more home repairs for legacy homeowners, increased homeownership, new homes on vacant lots, new community buildings and more businesses. Long term outcomes include improved public health and reduced criminal justice involvement, Day said.
Cambridge Mayor Lajan Cephas said she feels this is a framework for justice. With Cambridge's history of slavery, Jim Crow, discriminatory policies and segregation among wards, Cephas is hopeful the Just Communities designation will begin to rectify past harms.
"It's being unwound," Cephas said. "It's just great to finally address, you know, the financial instabilities and other opportunities that were held back in communities just like Cambridge."
Cephas said along with the investments made in the community, the Just Communities initiative pushes grant requests to the front of the line.
"I say, Gov. Moore, it's like you gave us platform shoes," she said. "It's very difficult competing against these other municipalities. They have better grant writers, better budgets. You know, they have comprehensive plans that they've been working on for years, and we're just now getting caught up."
Cephas wants to make it clear that these initiatives will not solely benefit Black residents, but will benefit all residents who have been affected by discriminatory policies and live within the Just Communities designated area, which encompasses much of downtown Cambridge and surrounding neighborhoods.
The Just Communities Act has faced pushback from Maryland Republican lawmakers, who called the initiative an unproductive government handout and unfair to Maryland taxpayers, according to a statement issued to the Baltimore Sun.
In a statement to the Star Democrat Friday morning, Maryland Senate Minority Leader Stephen Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) said, "Does anyone really believe pumping hundreds of millions into handpicked areas will build generational wealth?"
"This is wealth redistribution dressed up in equity language — it's socialism, plain and simple," the statement said.
But the initiative's proponents contend the Just Communities designations aim to ensure fairness among Maryland residents.
"It's the very picture of fairness as I was raised and taught to understand fairness," Day said. "Again, take something from somebody and you return it."
Cephas echoed Day's sentiments, pointing to the "unfair" practices that have held Cambridge back.
The community can check on updates for the Just Communities Designation at choosecambridge.com, where residents can sign up for public alerts via text or email.

title: 'Still matters today': Community to read famous Frederick Douglass speech on Saturday
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Still matters today': Community to read famous Frederick Douglass speech on Saturday

 July 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News

 EASTON — On July 5, 1852, Frederick Douglass asked a burning question in front of hundreds of abolitionists in Rochester, New York: "What to the Slave is the Fourth of July?"The Talbot County native, often considered the most important abolitionist and civil rights leader of his time, delivered an address that described why enslaved African Americans weren't afforded the same freedoms and liberties that could allow them to celebrate the anniversary of the Declaration of Independence like the rest of the nation.
Douglass' famous speech is still popular 173 years later. On Saturday, the Easton-based Frederick Douglass Honor Society is hosting an annual community reading. Local officials, community leaders, residents and children are reading aloud portions of the address on the lawn of the Talbot County Courthouse starting at 10 a.m.
Vickie Wilson, the society's treasurer, says this year's calendar couldn't have worked out any better, with the event falling on the same day Douglass spoke to the Rochester Ladies Anti-Slavery Society.
"What's really exciting for us this year is that the first time Douglass read this speech was on July 5, 1852," Wilson said. "And now, it falls again on July 5."
The Frederick Douglass Honor Society has held the reading annually since 2018, though it was put on pause last year for a separate event. Wilson says this year's return is exciting due to the diversity of people — in age, race, occupation and more — participating in the reading. Fifty-nine people are expected to step up to the podium.
"We live in a diverse community," Wilson said. "It's going to show the love that we have for this community as well."
Douglass in his 1852 speech explained the significantly different perspective enslaved people had on the Fourth of July holiday.
"What, to the American slave, is your 4th of July? I answer; a day that reveals to him, more than all other days in the year, the gross injustice and cruelty to which he is the constant victim," Douglass said.
He continued: "To him, your celebration is a sham; your boasted liberty, an unholy license; your national greatness, swelling vanity; your sounds of rejoicing are empty and heartless; your denunciation of tyrants, brass fronted impudence; your shouts of liberty and equality, hollow mockery; your prayers and hymns, your sermons and thanksgivings, with all your religious parade and solemnity, are, to Him, mere bombast, fraud, deception, impiety, and hypocrisy — a thin veil to cover up crimes which would disgrace a nation of savages."
Wilson says the Talbot County tradition during the week of Independence Day is a moving one. She encourages people, no matter how they celebrate the holiday the rest of the week, to attend on Saturday.
She said the speech is a "lot to unpack," but extremely powerful. It still resonates with her today, and she believes it does for many Talbot County residents.
"It still matters today," Wilson said. "And I often think it matters more today in the climate that we're in right now. Everything here about this speech is still relevant."

 The Cephas family's history is the history of Dorchester County.Ancestors fought in the Revolutionary War, worked in the fields as slaves on plantations and owned the largest Black-owned farm in the county following the Civil War. Today, Cephas family members hold key political positions in a number of Dorchester County towns and beyond.
For Brandy James, being part of the Cephas family means pride, resilience and honoring generations of strength, leadership and cultural identity in the Black community.
"The struggles of our ancestors were not in vain and have come to fruition," she said.
James, a Federalsburg council member, is the daughter of Hurlock Mayor Charles Cephas. James's cousins are Cambridge Mayor Lajan Cephas and Cambridge City Council President Sputty Cephas.
If one was not told before a city council meeting that Lajan used to change Sputty's diapers, you'd likely never know that they're siblings, but they're a dynamic duo in Cambridge's local government.
"I see it as my mission and my purpose to serve," Lajan said, but she didn't just mean as mayor. For the Cephases, politics can be a conduit to care for and serve the community, but it is not the main player.
"It doesn't have to be political to show that you care or that it's okay to help your neighbor. It's about the human aspect of it all. It's about being a good neighbor and considering your community as an extension of your family. That's how I see it," James said.
The Cephas Family History
Around 1817, Moses Cephas and his family were slaves at a property near the Fork Neck area — situated between Cambridge and Vienna — where Charles, the self-proclaimed acting patriarch, said the family had "deep roots."
That is until after the Civil War, when Moses and Josiah Cephas inherited a large farm near Vienna, becoming the proprietors of the largest Black-owned farm in Dorchester County. The Cephases sold produce, including corn and tomatoes, on Race Street in Cambridge and leased out part of the farm to white individuals, Charles said.
Lajan said along with farmers, there are watermen and sailors in the Cephas lineage.
Charles said that during slavery, some Cephas family members were captured by the renowned slave hunter Patty Cannon. Slave hunters like Cannon practiced in the illegal slave trade, also known as the Reverse Underground Railroad, where they found and captured escaped and freed slaves to return them back to slavery.
During this time, family members' names were changed from Cephas with an A to Cephus with a U to facilitate their transport across state lines back to the South.
Perhaps one of the most fascinating Cephas family members — which difficult to determine considering the incredible cast of characters — is Richard "Big Dick" Cephas.
A fictional version of his life where he fights in the Haitian revolution and falls in love with a young American woman is presented in Kenneth Roberts' best-selling novel "Lydia Bailey." But Charles said after speaking to several historians, he knows the real truth.
"He ran away from slavery and he went all the way to Boston, Massachusetts, and he ended up being in the British Army," he said. "He fought against America, he was captured and put in prison there, and they were able to trace it because he was such a disruptor that he caused a riot in the prison."
Being a disrupter is sometimes a necessary agent of change.
In 1962, Charles made history as one of the first Black people to graduate from the newly desegregated Cambridge High School. After serving on the town council for two decades, acting as president for one of those, he became the first Black mayor of the town of Hurlock in 2021 and was re-elected last year.
In 2023, James became the first Black lawmaker in Federalsburg's 200-year history. The following year, Lajan became the second Black female mayor of Cambridge and Sputty was re-elected onto the City Council and elected by his fellow council members as council president.
Cephas family values
For the Cephases, faith is at the center of all they do.
"You know, that's the foundation that we come from, and not only that, we take the last name of Cephas to a deeper meaning, more or less than the meaning that you see in the Bible," Lajan said. "I guess anyone who is a Christian or anyone that's read the Bible, Jesus had the moment where he referred to Peter as a Cephas, and that was essentially the foundation of how Christianity was established."
Charles has 14 children and 49 grandchildren — maybe a few more, maybe a few less. It's easy to lose count he said. At 75 years old, Charles said he's excited to watch the legacy he has helped build continue to prosper and grow.
For Lajan and Brandy, it is also important that Cephas is not synonymous with politics.
Both have children who pursued careers outside of politics. For both, it is important that their children carry the long-withstanding Cephas values into whatever they do.
"They feel the pressure to do what they're supposed to do so we can make God happy. That's their pressure," said Lajan about her sons. "You know, to govern themselves accordingly."
Lajan said she wants the people of Dorchester County to know that while the Cephases are deeply rooted, they are a small piece of the larger puzzle and beautiful fabric of all the other names in the county.
Some of the other names may even be Cephases.
Many formerly enslaved individuals either had their names changed or changed their names after obtaining freedom. Because of this, Charles said there are many Cephases out there that likely don't even know they are Cephases.
Charles said the descendants they've been able to trace can be located all over the U.S., including Alaska. Recently, they were able to trace Cephases in Japan. In the next few months, there will be a massive Cephas family reunion with descendants from all over the country and beyond.

title: Hispanic pastor was targeted

Hispanic pastor was targeted

 July 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox

 That ICE would arrest the Rev. Daniel Espinal was a foregone conclusion. To put it simply, he was targeted.ICE has been creating self-serving catches across the nation which both polish its badge and dispirit Hispanic communities. Doubtless, members of Pastor Espinal's church should be sure that ICE will be worshipping with them this Sunday, prayers in Spanish offered inside, whilst outside agents will be checking license plates, awaiting their drivers. There will be no coffee hour.
This has happened before in Easton.
In 1994, the then-INS raided an apartment complex, hauling off at least a dozen undocumented Hispanics. I represented many of their cases before the Asylum Office in Arlington, Virginia, and in the U.S. Immigration Court in Baltimore. As in those days I pastored a store front chapel in downtown Easton, I made it privately known to our Hispanics to enter by the alley door for the following Sunday's Spanish mass. Mass concluded, our strategy was to have those with green cards or who were citizens to socialize outside the front door. The INS agents, whom we expected, were baffled, even angry, to be greeted by our legals – while other worshippers squeezed into the sacristy, invisible through the chapel's front windows – all of them documented within the immigration system, yet vulnerable to agents eager only to collect vast numbers.
To victimize prominent members of a targeted community has been well learned by ICE. When Herman Goering established the Third Reich's Gestapo in 1933, their methods were to first target such prominent Jews as rabbis and cantors, congregation and community leaders, elected civic leaders and teachers, thus dispiriting and creating fear within the remaining Jewish families. Those secret state police, taught to sniff out their fears, sent Jews off to the Alligator Alcatraz's of their time. It's an old, old story. It has happened in every civilization in recorded history.
THE RT. REV. JOEL MARCUS JOHNSON

Easton

title: ICE arrest of pastor stops church services
author: Lily Tierney
content:
ICE arrest of pastor stops church services

 July 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 634
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Church services at Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama have ceased since the arrest of its pastor, Daniel Fuentes Espinal, on Monday, July 21.Espinal was getting ready to enjoy his McDonalds breakfast when he was pulled over by an unmarked car on state Route 322 near Moton Park around 8 a.m.
Not only has Espinal been taken from his wife and three children, but also his congregation of 80. The parishioners currently aren't meeting out of fear the same will happen to them.
"You know, the members of the congregation believe, and rightfully so, that if this could happen to somebody with Pastor Fuentes Espinal's stature and position within the community, then nobody's safe," said Len Foxwell, a close family friend of Espinal's.
The Rt. Rev. Joel Marcus Johnson, a bishop from Easton, said canceling services now is wise.
"It's wise on their part, I think because we know that ICE would be showing up," Johnson said.
Johnson knows this because he lived it in 1994 when U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Services — the precursor to ICE — showed up to one of his Spanish services at a storefront chapel in Easton.
Johnson, clergy and the congregation came up with a plan where the undocumented immigrants went out the back door and those with green cards or citizenship went out the front.
"It really, really angered INS," Johnson said.
Johnson said arresting high-ranking members of the church is a targeted approach that is not new.
"It's one of the tried and true methods for dispiriting or deflating the hearts of these communities," he said.
Matthew Peters, executive director of the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, said he is not aware of any recent ICE arrests in churches on the Mid-Shore, but due to uncertain policy changes, fear is widespread.
COMMUNITY RALLIESEspinal was detained by two U.S. Customs and Immigration Enforcement agents and taken to the Salisbury Field Office. He was quickly transferred to the Baltimore ICE detention center, where he remained for three nights. On Thursday, Espinal was transferred to an ICE detention center in Louisiana, where he will stay until his hearing, which has not been scheduled yet.
Espinal has been in the U.S. since 2001, has no criminal record and has been attempting to secure citizenship legally for years. He has been described as a pillar of the community. A GoFundMe created by Foxwell has raised over $44,000 to cover attorney's fees and other expenses.
ICE said in a statement to the Star Democrat that Espinal was arrested for overstaying his six-month visa.
"Daniel Omar Fuentes Espinal is an illegal alien from Honduras who was arrested by ICE on July 21, in Easton, Maryland," the statement said. "Fuentes entered the United States on a 6-month visa and never left in 24 years. It is a federal crime to overstay the authorized period of time granted under a visitors visa."
Community members, religious leaders and politicians have rallied behind Espinal, holding protests in both Easton and Baltimore since his arrest. On Friday, over 150 people showed up to support Espinal with a rally on U.S. Route 50 in Easton.
According to Foxwell, around 300 people showed up to a rally in Baltimore on Monday. He said he was nervous that people wouldn't turn out because they don't know Espinal, but that was not the case.
"I didn't know if we would be playing to an empty McKeldin Square, but the place was full," Foxwell said.
The rally began with a march from the square to the Fallon Courthouse, the site of the temporary ICE detention center where Espinal was held before being transferred to Louisiana.
Another rally for Pastor Espinal will be held in Easton Friday, Aug. 1, from 5:30 to 6:30 p.m. at the intersection of Dover Street and Route 50. The rally will be hosted by the Talbot County Democratic Forum and the Talbot County Democratic Central Committee.

title: 'Critically important': Frederick Douglass Day brings insight
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
'Critically important': Frederick Douglass Day brings insight

 September 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 529

 EASTON — Cloudy and rainy weather did not stop hundreds of people from attending Frederick Douglass Day at the Talbot County Court House in Easton on Saturday.Douglass has strong roots in Talbot County and throughout the Eastern Shore.
Born in Talbot County in 1818, Frederick Augustus Washington Bailey Douglass was enslaved for 20 years in Baltimore and on Talbot County farms. He fled north in 1838 and changed his name to Frederick Douglass. His brilliance, eloquence and courage, quickly brought him to the forefront of the abolitionist movement.
He was known for his skills as an orator, with many of his speeches remembered to this day.
"I would say critically important," James Young, the event's publicist, said said about Douglass. "He's one of, if not the most respected and important figures in the history of the region. I think it's important for anybody to know more about his life and his work but especially for people who come from where he came from."
Frederick Douglass Day kicked off with a parade led by Grand Marshal Childlene Brooks, former president of the Frederick Douglass Honor Society. The parade featured local groups including Building African American Minds, Easton High School NJROTC Color Guard, Polaris Village Academy, and the Easton and Oxford Fire Departments and many more.
This year, a big focus for the Frederick Douglass Honor Society was getting the younger generation involved in celebrating Douglass.
Gabriella Thompson, the mistress of ceremony, described as a "ambitious 14-year-old entering her freshman year of high school," and Javion Jones, a 15-year-old minister at Union Baptist Church, were some of the youth featured throughout the day.
"I would say there has been some effort to get new people involved. As you know, a lot of people on the committee itself are getting up there," Young said. "So it's a thing that we want to keep going for the foreseeable future, and so at some point you've got to bring in some some fresh blood."
Multiple local leaders attended and participated in Frederick Douglass Day.
Jaelon Moaney, vice chair of the Maryland Commission on African American History and Culture, recited a famous speech by Douglass. The honor society believes having connections like Moaney are important for the success of the society and the annual event.
"Having that connection to African-American history more broadly, as well as current African-American issues, I think is very important," Young said. "That's also something that we try to focus on with the keynote speaker that we bring every year. It's somebody who can bring a perspective of speaking on Douglas but also how he kind of fits into the history of African-American intellectual philosophy."
In an email following the event, Moaney emphasized his own Eastern Shore roots, similar to those of Douglass.
"I, too, am from and decidedly of Talbot," Moaney said. "The Bailey and Moaney families remain connected today. Although two agitators separated by time, my chest began to swell with inexplicable energy while echoing the words delivered on November 25, 1878 from exactly where he stood nearly two centuries prior. As the country commemorates the semiquincentennial and Talbot reaches its 365th anniversary next year, I'm both troubled and moved by the parallels of reality that this experience has revealed."

title: Columbus Day honors Italian American resilience
author: CHRIS CORCHIARINO
content:
Columbus Day honors Italian American resilience

 October 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CHRIS CORCHIARINO | Section: Columns 
 
 717
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every October, the debate over Columbus Day versus Indigenous Peoples' Day resurfaces, framed as a choice between two communities. Yet Italian Americans, like Indigenous people, have endured marginalization and discrimination. These are American stories of resilience that deserve recognition. Turning their struggles into a zero-sum culture war dishonors both cultures.As the son of an Italian immigrant, I support a day for recognizing Indigenous People. I wish those pushing this narrative used the other 364 days to address Indigenous poverty, land rights and generational neglect — not just symbolic gestures. Importantly, we don't need to erase the hard-won recognition that Italian Americans fought for through Columbus Day. How it came to exist is important.
On March 14, 1891, New Orleans Police Chief David Hennessy was murdered. As he lay dying, he whispered "Dagoes" — a slur for Italians. Anti-Italian hysteria ignited. The mayor ordered police to "arrest every Italian you come across," and families hid as vigilantes roamed the streets.
When nine Italian immigrants were acquitted and three had mistrials, a mob stormed the jail, dragging 11 out—some shot, some hanged, their bodies mutilated as crowds cheered. It remains one of the largest single mass lynchings in U.S. history.
The press celebrated it as righteous justice. Theodore Roosevelt called it a "rather good thing," reflecting widespread contempt for Italians as racially inferior. To ease diplomatic tensions with Italy, President Benjamin Harrison declared a one-time Columbus Day in 1892 — an acknowledgment born from violence and tragedy.
For Italian Americans Columbus Day isn't primarily about Christopher Columbus. It is about survival, recognition, and pride in the face of discrimination. Italian immigrants had been celebrating it informally since 1866, using the explorer as a symbol of their right to belong in America.
At the turn of the 20th century, Italian immigrants were among America's lowest-paid workers, toiling in coal mines and laying railroad tracks under brutal conditions. Many fell victim to the padrone system, where labor bosses trapped them in debt, locked them in camps and withheld wages.
During World War II, thousands of Italians were designated "enemy aliens," facing curfews, travel restrictions and property seizures. Some were interned.
The Ku Klux Klan actively fought against Columbus Day recognition. They campaigned to strip it as a state holiday in Oregon, burned a cross at a 1924 celebration in Pennsylvania and blocked a Columbus statue installation in Virginia in 1927.
Yet Italian Americans persisted. Through decades of advocacy, Columbus Day became a federal holiday in 1968. Parades celebrated not just an explorer, but Italian Americans who contributed to society — scientists, artists, laborers, soldiers, entrepreneurs. A tradition started by blue-collar immigrants who scraped together money to erect statues and organize celebrations.
Today, the push to replace Columbus Day often overlooks this history. For Italian Americans, it has always been about their own resilience, not defending Columbus's atrocities. Yet those who object to the name never propose renaming the holiday to preserve Italian American recognition. Instead, they seek to eliminate it entirely — erasing the history of how Italian immigrants were treated and why this day mattered.
Even in recent history, when Columbus statues are toppled — statues funded by immigrant communities scraping together pennies — crowds cheer, but those cheers are celebrating the erasure of working-class immigrant history.
This erasure is troubling because bigotry toward Italian Americans hasn't disappeared. Mafia stereotypes remain acceptable punchlines. Mocking Italian accents is still considered harmless comedy. I grew up seeing this bigotry visited upon my father — but like other Italians, he persevered.
We shouldn't force a choice between honoring Italian American struggles and recognizing Indigenous peoples. Both histories deserve celebration.
If "Columbus" is the obstacle, the productive conversation would be about renaming the October holiday while still honoring Italian American heritage. However, when that is not the topic and the discussion ignores this history, it's difficult to pass it as anything more than anti-Italian bigotry. We shouldn't dismiss the struggles of Italian immigrants who, like my father, built lives in America fueled by the promise of the American Dream. It's a uniquely American story that should be told. Their story — the persecution, resilience and contribution to the American fabric — deserves to be remembered. Pitting groups against each other in an annual culture war is wrong and not in keeping with the promise of America.
Chris Corchiarino is a Maryland attorney and Queen Anne's County resident.
